isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - IC BUS SERVICE MANUAL - BUS BODY CONSTRUCTION - BODY PANEL REMOVAL PROCEDURE

svcproc.title: BODY PANEL REMOVAL PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: All body panel joints are assembled with mechanical fasteners. Each joint is designed in such a way that it is imperative to replace all body panels and fasteners with OEM equipment. All body panels are required to meet federal standard FMVSS 221. This standard establishes that all body panels must meet 60% joint strength requirements. Because of this standard and International design, it is very difficult to remove certain body panels. The procedure below will simplify what is required to replace damaged body panels, in most conditions. Only trained technicians should perform the repair work.

step1.para: Remove all rivets from the damaged panel ( Figure 27). The rivets can be removed by using a large chisel and a #10 drill bit. Once the head or cap of the rivet has been removed, the drill bit can be used to drill the sleeve of the rivet out of the body panel ( Figure 28).

step2.para: Before the body panel is totally removed, notice how the panels are overlapped. It is important that the body panel be installed the same way it was removed.
It may be necessary to remove rub rails, depending on the location of the damage ( Figure 29). Use procedure 1 above to perform this task.

step1.para: Inspect the area to be repaired. Clean and treat any metal if required. If the replacement panel has optional equipment, such as a luggage box compartment or a skirt-mounted air conditioner, the cut-out modification should be made to the replacement panel prior to the initial installation.
